subject: History
title: Insulin's Lifesaving Story
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Insulin's Lifesaving Story.

hook.text: Before 1922, a diagnosis of Type 1 diabetes meant death within months. Then a dog experiment changed everything.

buildup.text: Frederick Banting and Charles Best extracted insulin from a dog's pancreas and injected it into a dying boy.

discovery.text: Leonard Thompson, age 14, woke from a diabetic coma. Within days, he was walking and eating normally.

twist.text: Banting sold the insulin patent for $1, saying it belonged to the world. Pharmaceutical companies disagreed.

climax.text: Today, insulin costs pennies to produce but can cost hundreds of dollars per vial in the US.

punchline.text: A $1 patent became a billion-dollar industry.

quiz.question: Why did Banting sell the insulin patent for just $1?
options: He didn't think it would be profitable
He believed a lifesaving drug belonged to the world
The Canadian government forced him to sell cheaply
